div.head: The Chicago Times: Wednesday, August 1, 1888.

head.p:
PUBLISHED EVERY MORNING
(AT THE TIMES BUILDING)
Corner of Washington Street and Fifth Avenue
BY JAMES J. WEST.

div.p: INTEREST in the conditions of the Chicago factory girls is aroused. Nothing proves this more conclusively than the present extraordinary demand for THE TIMES.

Yesterday’s revelations were of a character decidedly surprising to the good people who believe everybody in Chicago should be contented and happy. Today’s revelations will add to their amazement. Tomorrow they will probably be stunned.
The inquiry is in good hands. It will not be abridged. THE TIMES will push it to the end.
Extra editions of THE TIMES of Monday and Tuesday have been run off to meet the demand for the articles already published. These papers can be had at the business office at 2 cents per copy.

If that jersey concern has any money to spare it should distribute it among its unfortunate female employes instead of wasting it in paying lawyers to bring a buncombe lawsuit. All THE TIMES is uneasy about is that the case will not be permitted to go to trial.
THE TIMES can never Rip-Pent for what it said about the Never-Rip jersey
How will the Never-Rip people have it - in small or large bills?

div.head: Briefly Told.
div.p: The Never-Rip Jersey company has beguna libel suit against THE TIMES for $50,000.
